content: yeah, but it's often not enough - ie protobuf types don't really match _that_ well to what we often end up using, ie no fixed-size lists for example for hashes, so you end up with this semi-typed API anyway - at that point, swagger et al offer similar amounts of "spec" on top of json, and for when we need performance, we use native encodings - for example, downloading an eth2 beacon state  is done using SSZ, in the rest API (even though json can also be used) - using a canonical protobuf mapping for SSZ, the beacon state would still be "undertyped" and inefficient, comparatively speaking

author: pipermerriam
content: I haven't seen anything compelling for using something other than REST or JSON-RPC.  They are both already widely supported and adopted amidst the tooling that has been built for our ecosystem for many years now. I concur with  <@!449019668296892420> that the "typing" argument isn't compelling.  I tend to not find the performance argument compelling enough to justify adding a 3rd type of transport.  My support at this stage would be for REST or JSON-RPC with REST being my preference. (just putting my voice into the cauldron)

author: ryanleeschneider
content:
I think the main take away here is that IMO Peter's arguments against gRPC apply to this new API as well.  gRPC is by design stateful and bi-directional, as would be any hand-rolled websocket protocol.

> Generally, the dumber and more boring a protocol is, the simpler it is to interface. At the end of the day, the goal of Ethereum is to bring developers together, so we should always prefer simplicity over other advantages.

I'd vote for REST just to make it very clear this is a separate interaction than the legacy eth1 API, but would personally be fine with a _truly_ stateless JSONRPC API as well.  I think building statefulness into the _transport_ used for eth1<->eth2 communication is overly limiting at this point in time.  It's _much_ easier to go from a stateless API to a stateful one if statefulness is ultimately required, it's very hard to go the other way.

Likewise I'd vote for any required signing etc to be built into the protocol itself rather than for example requiring HTTPS for the REST endpoint.
